title: SoCal R Users Group (SoCal RUG): Book club  - Information Rules: A Strategic Guide to the Network Economy  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
In Information Rules, authors Shapiro and Varian reveal that many classic economic concepts can provide the insight and understanding necessary to succeed in the information age. They argue that if managers seriously want to develop effective strategies for competing in the new economy, they must understand the fundamental economics of information technology. Whether information takes the form of software code or recorded music, is published in a book or magazine, or even posted on a website, managers must know how to evaluate the consequences of pricing, protecting, and planning new versions of information products, services, and systems. The first book to distill the economics of information and networks into practical business strategies, Information Rules is a guide to the winning moves that can help business leaders navigate successfully through the tough decisions of the information economy.

The format will be that the leader will prepare a short summary of the material and present it to the group. We will then discuss the material and do some exercises.

The expectations are that you will attend regularly. If you cannot make a commitment to attend, please wait until the next book club starts. It is also expected that participants will take turns being the leader. The leader should prepare a summary of the material that was read and present it to the group.

We will meet each week, Monday between 4:00 and 5:00 PM PST for six weeks (Jan 17 to Feb 21). In the six weeks, ten chapters will be covered

Book: Title: Information Rules: A Strategic Guide to the Network Economy
Dead Tree: https://www.amazon.com/dp/087584863X/

Signing up: When you sign-up you will be placed on the waiting list. We always have a lot of interest but the book club is a significant commitment. The coordinator will confirm your commitment. Please make sure that you get meet-up emails.

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): January Lightning Talks: interactive apps, logistic regression, purrr & more  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
January Lightning Series

Do you have something new you'd like to share with the group or a favorite package you just learned about? We'd love to hear from the community in a series of lightning talks on January 24th at 12 ET.

(date had changed from January 17th)

Lightning Talks by:
Bryan Butler - Building Interactive Apps with RMarkdown and Reticulate
Matt Curcio - Logistic regression
Anubhuti Mishra - Automate parts of your R project w/ Project Template
Nithin M - Purrr, A multipurpose package

Talks & Speaker Bios:
Bryan will use the R Markdown format to build an interactive text visualization app in Python. Using Python, we will compare and visualize survey text, and then create an interactive= web-based html app using R Markdown that can be opened in any browser. We'll cover a few unique tips to making clean visuals using Python & Plotly as well as and advanced NLP tool such as Google Universal Sentence Encoder & UMAP.

Matt has been a Biochemist, a salesperson, and a Kindergarten Teacher. He is now teaching himself Data Science. Matt will discuss the importance of logistic regression with a simple example.

Anubhuti Mishra is a Senior Data Scientist at Palladium Group. She creates data science products for global HIV and COVID-19 health programs. This talk will demonstrate how to use ProjectTemplate package - If you hate loading packages, reading in datasets, or loading functions spread across several scripts - automate all your project startup steps with 2 lines of code.

Nithin is a PhD candidate in Macroeconomics at the Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur India and has received a grant to participate at the noRth R conference organized by University of Minnesota. The talk will be a demonstration of the versatility of one of my favorite package purrr . The live coding session will demonstrate use of purr for common data cleaning, ggplots and rendering Rmarkdown reports.

If interested in future lightning talks, you can share your abstract here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScuZDGDx3aOm6P0jzm8pXPkMryN5iv4PBhq1Ghy3BH-9JGcAw/viewform

Lightning talks can be anywhere from 3 to 10 minutes :)

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Automating Clinical Trial Master File Migration&Information Extraction  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register Here for Free: https://hubs.li/Q0114pgq0

Pharmaceutical Companies who conduct clinical trials, looking to get new treatments to market as quickly as possible, possess a high volume of documents. Millions of documents can be created as part of one trial and are stored in a document management system. In case migrating these documents to a new system is needed - for example, when a pharma company acquires the rights to a drug or trial - all these documents must often be read manually in order to classify them and extract metadata that is legally required and must be accurate. Traditionally, this migration is a long, complex, and labor-intensive process.

We present a solution based on the natural language processing (NLP) system which provides:

- Speed – 80% reduction of manual labor and migration timeline, proven in major real-world projects
- State of the art accuracy – based on Spark NLP for Healthcare, integrated in a human-in-the-loop solution
- End-to-end, secure and compliant solution – Air-gap deployment, GxP and GAMP 5 validated

We will share lessons learned from an end-to-end migration process of the trial master file in Novartis.

Register Here for Free: https://hubs.li/Q0114pgq0

title: Montreal R User Group: What Can You Expect for ML in 2022  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:

As 2021 comes to a close, the challenges of productionizing and scaling team’s machine learning projects still remain at large. With all the big advancements in AI/ML, what are some actionable learnings for your team?

In this webinar join us as we talk about:

- Noteworthy highlights in the AI/ML space from 2021
- Upcoming trends in ML/AI for 2022
- Market movement (AIIA member valuations, acquisition and consolidation)
- The shift to ‘Data Monitoring’ from ‘Model monitoring’ OR the evolution of ‘DataOps’ - reference Andrew Ng
- Bedfellows for 2022: How hardware will meet ISV e.g. Nvidia/HPE and the AIIA ecosystem.
- Winners & Losers - Best of breed vs Production ML on ‘so-called’ E2E solutions. The new data providers and the role of analytics.

Learn more and register here: https://info.datascience.salon/what-can-you-expect-for-ml-in-2022

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] The Story of CapitaLogix with Kuberre and Dask  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Learn more and register here: https://us06web.zoom.us/webinar/register/4316336246216/WN_XHk74YHDQuGrLxXCLXTGrg

The quantitative hedge fund manager, CapitaLogix, was heavily dependent upon their legacy “on-premise” hardware/software stack vendor in order to run their proprietary pattern mining algorithms. Join us for a compelling look into the real costs, limitations, and learning that convinced CEO Howard Getson and his team to embrace Dask and make the move to the cloud. Hear from Kumar Metlapalli (Kuberre Systems CEO) as he lays out how he, and his team of quant technology experts at Kuberre, were able to deliver the massively parallel, 100% Python, environment the CapitaLogix team requires while driving out 97% of the legacy costs. This story demonstrates the power and value that can be realized by combining cloud computing platforms with Dask and Kuberre’s QTPy (Quantitative Techniques in Python) data science optimization solution.

Learn more and register here: https://us06web.zoom.us/webinar/register/4316336246216/WN_XHk74YHDQuGrLxXCLXTGrg

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Agile Data Labeling  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Learn more and register here: https://signup.watchful.io/hand-labeling-is-harmful-webinar-0

Data and AI have never been more essential to businesses of all sizes, across every industry around the world. To become truly data-driven, organizations need to provide decision-makers with labeled data that’s relevant to their analyses. In order to deliver impactful ML applications, organizations need to be able to efficiently create training data.

The growing frustration among data scientists is driving the need for the Agile Manifesto of Data Labeling.

A successful Agile Manifesto of Data Labeling should begin with the same principle of reactivity. Successful preparation of training data involves cooperation, feedback, and discipline.

Speakers:

Shayan Mohanty is the CEO and Co-Founder of Watchful, a company that largely automates the process of creating labeled training data. He has a decade leading data engineering teams at various companies including Facebook, where he served as lead for the stream processing team responsible for processing 100% of the ads metrics data for all FB products. He is also a Guest Scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory and has given talks on topics ranging from Automata Theory to Machine Teaching.

Jennifer Prendki is the CEO of Alectio, a disruptive B2B AI company pioneering the concept of DataPrepOps. Previously, she was the VP of Machine Learning at Figure Eight–the company that pioneered data labeling–the Chief Data Scientist at Atlassian and a Senior Manager of Data Science in the Search Team at Walmart. She has spent most of her career building and scaling high performing machine learning teams and developing data-driven cultures. She was trained as a scientist with a PhD in Particle Physics from Sorbonne University.

All attendees will:

- Gain a basic understanding of the principles of agile data labeling
Learn about how agile data labeling can be applied to your machine learning pipelines
- Explore and discover two new platforms that help you and your enterprise transform the way you label data

Learn more and register here: https://signup.watchful.io/hand-labeling-is-harmful-webinar-0

title: CalgaryR: Validation of the underlying construct of survey instruments  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Please welcome our speaker, Cherri Zhang, Data Manager and Analyst, Department of Psychology, University of Calgary. We are meeting virtually on Wednesday, January 12, 2022, at 5:30 pm

Abstract

Background: Diagnosis and management of concussion depends on post-concussive symptom (PCS) ratings. One approach to validation of PCS rating scales is to examine their factor structure and to test measurement invariance (MI).

Purpose: To validate the underlying construct of survey instruments across raters, groups, and time using confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) and MI through the implementation of lavaan package in R.

Methods: Four models were implemented: correlated two- and three-factor models and bifactor models with two and three specific factors across four levels of MI. MI is a stepwise approach that compares nested models by adding increasingly stringent constraints to model parameters. The MI levels are configural, weak, strong, and strict. Models were compared using fit indices such as root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA), comparative fit index (CFI), and Tucker-Lewis index (TLI). MI is established when the fit of the more stringent model (e.g., strong invariance) is no worse compared to the one with more relaxed assumptions (e.g., weak invariance), as indicated by fit statistics. Additionally, OmegaH was used to assess the bifactor models to estimate the proportion of observed variance in total and subscale scores that could be attributed to the underlying factors.

Results: The bifactor models displayed better fit indices; however, model convergence took up to several hours with the three-factor model having convergence problems during initial CFA. The correlated models showed greater parsimony, shorter convergence time, and less convergence issues. Strong to strict invariance were established in all models.

Conclusion: The findings support a two-factor model of the Health Behaviour Inventory (HBI). The bifactor model showed the best fit, suggesting that ratings on the HBI also can be captured by a general factor. The results provide further validation of the HBI, supporting its use in childhood concussion research and clinical practice.

Please join us and learn together.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Your Laptop is More Capable than you Think: Large Data with {disk.frame}  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Another in a series of talks about using R with data too big for RAM, we have ZJ Dai discussing {disk.frame}.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

About the Talk:
Every R user has run into the "cannot allocate vector of size xxxB." error at some point. For most applications, R needs to load the data in its entirety into RAM. However, RAM is a precious resource and often runs out.

The {disk.frame} package solves this issue by providing a framework to manipulate data on disk and minimize RAM usage. By using {disk.frame}, the user can perform analysis on much larger data than is ordinarily possible with R. A modern laptop with {disk.frame} can handle 100GB's of data.

About ZJ:
ZJ is a data scientist with over fourteen years of experience in the banking and tech start-up space. He is the lead developer of {disk.frame}.

The talk will begin at 7 PM America/New_York and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: R-Ladies Boulder: RLadies #22: Frequentist & Bayesian Random Effects Models in R: RStan Tutorial  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
This month's guest speaker Amanda Koepke will present on random effects modeling in RStan:

A common problem in science, medicine, and other fields is the need to combine independent measurements (taken over multiple days, or at different labs, or using different measurement methods) into a consensus estimate in a way that recognizes explicitly the contributions that different sources of uncertainty (i.e., within-study uncertainties and between-study differences) make to the overall uncertainty. Many methods exist for this, and past studies have compared the performance of different estimation approaches, however little attention has been paid to Bayesian approaches. In this talk, I will briefly describe my work extending these estimator comparisons to Bayesian models and exploring which approaches are best for common data scenarios at NIST (https://www.nist.gov/). I will then give a short tutorial on how to implement this type of Bayesian analysis in R using RStan. The Hamiltonian Monte Carlo used in RStan provides a very efficient way to explore the posterior distribution and allows for the most natural definition of specialized probability distributions. However, it can be tricky to consistently obtain valid samples when trying to fit many simulated datasets with realistic simulation settings. I'll describe some of the issues I encountered and how to deal with some common RStan warnings.

title: R-Ladies Santiago: Club de lectura del libro "Data Feminism" (sesión 7)  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
El próximo martes 18 de enero nos reuniremos para nuestra última sesión del club de lectura sobre libro "Data Feminism", de Catherine D'Ignazio y Lauren F. Klein. Este libro muestra una nueva forma de abordar la ciencia de datos y la ética de datos basada en ideas del feminismo interseccional. Se puede acceder de forma gratuita en: https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/

Esta sexta sesión estará a cargo de Alejandra Tapia Silva (https://twitter.com/aleants). Alejandra es Doctora en Estadística y fundadora de RLadies Talca. Durante la sesión comentaremos el capítulo 7, "Show your work", en el que se presenta el séptimo principio del feminismo de datos: hacer el trabajo visible.

- ¿Qué pasa si no puedo leer en inglés?
¡Puedes participar igual! La persona encargada de cada sesión hará una síntesis de los puntos más importantes, así que incluso si no puedes revisar el libro, podrás aprender sobre este tema :)

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
El evento se realizará a través de la plataforma Zoom. El día del taller compartiremos la contraseña en los comentarios del evento.

Simisani has a history of working in the higher education industry having been working at the Department of Computer Science at the University of Botswana as a Teaching Assistant since 2016. She graduated with her Masters of Science in Computer Information Systems where her research work was based on Information Retrieval in Authorship Identification using authors’ writing styles PAN at CLEF. PAN is a series of scientific events and shared tasks on digital text forensics and stylometry. Prior to that, she worked as a Business Analyst at the Gauteng Department of Education working on data management and business intelligence in South Africa. She also holds a Bachelor’s degree in Business Information Systems and is due to complete a Post Graduate Diploma in Education, a teacher/trainer qualification in October 2021. She is part of the Ladies in R Botswana based in the University of Botswana and is an assistant in Health Informatics Africa.

title: R-Ladies Bucharest: R-Ladies #19 Build a new habit in 2022: Tidy Tuesday  [Virtual] , Romania, Europe
description:
Join us for a new session on the 25th of January, 7PM EET ! We continue our meetups with #goodRvibes and a challenge to engage in new habits.

Title: Build a new habit in 2022! Tidy Tuesday

#TidyTuesday is a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. An emphasis is placed on understanding how to summarize and arrange data to make meaningful charts with ggplot2, tidyr, dplyr, and other tools in the tidyverse ecosystem.

This meetup will be hands-on: after a brief introduction of #TidyTuesday and the weekly dataset, everyone will have a chance to explore the data and then share their work. Whether you want to practice exploratory visualization, apply a new analytical technique, try out a new plot theme or just learn tidyverse things from others, #TidyTuesday is for you.

To get a sense for #TidyTuesday ahead of time, check out the hashtag on Twitter, explore past datasets or check out David Robinson's screencasts below:

https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeiiqmVK07qhY-wvg3IZiZQ

Registration is free, but mandatory via meetup. We shall meet on zoom, and the link will be updated on the day of the event ( PIN for entrance should be sent by email ~2hours before meeting start).

title: AthensR: Introduction to Rtistry using {ggplot2} in R  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
Happy new Year!

We are happy to announce our next meetup which will serve as an introduction to Rtistry using {ggplot2} in R. Artists in the R community have been using the rtistry hashtag to demonstrate their gorgeous, dynamic art using only the R programming language. Their creations are amazing! That's why, we have the great pleasure to be hosting Meghan Harris.

➡️ About the trainer:
Meghan Harris is a self-taught R user that is a data integration specialist at the University at Buffalo and the Erie County government of New York. Meghan’s work focuses on integrating opioid-related data sources and creating custom reports, dashboards, and solutions using the R programming language. In Meghan’s spare time, Meghan creates generative art in the R programming language, called Rtistry.

Website: https://thetidytrekker.com/
Twitter: @meghansharris (https://twitter.com/meghansharris) Don't forget to follow Meghan on Twitter, she has always been sharing amazing aRt creations using R!

➡️ About the workshop
If you’ve ever seen pictures of generative art made in R and wondered if you could ever create art like that, the answer is “Yes.” In this introductory presentation, we will briefly go over the basics of creating generative art in R (Rtistry) using the ggplot2 package. This presentation will go over the common geoms (geometries), aesthetics, layering, and functions that can be used for Rtistry creation. The presentation will conclude with a live code review session of one Rtistry pieces. Full annotated code will be shared with participants for further practice and use.

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Teach Me How to Google  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Workshop description:

Googling for code help is something that all data scientists (at all career stages) do. But figuring out how to get the information you need back can be incredibly challenging, particularly for new coders. In this talk, we’ll discuss strategies for refining your queries to increase your chances of finding informative solutions.
https://ucsb-meds.github.io/teach-me-how-to-google/#1

About the speaker:

Sam Csik (pronounced “chick”) is the Data Training Coordinator at the National Center for Ecological Analysis & Synthesis (NCEAS) located at UC Santa Barbara, where she is working to develop and teach data science training curricula for the Master’s of Environmental Data Science (MEDS) program and other data science initiatives across NCEAS and UCSB. She is also co-organizer of R-Ladies Santa Barbara, a local data science group which works to promote diversity in the R community. In her spare time, you’ll typically find her hiking with her pup or cooking family dinners with friends.

title: R-Ladies Seattle: Reactor x PNW Tech Community Networking  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join us at a networking event hosted by the Microsoft Reactor and partners - the PNW chapters of Seattle PyLadies, R-Ladies Seattle, and Data Circles. This is an opportunity to meet folks and hear from a few incredible community groups.

Register here or on the Reactor's Meetup page: https://www.meetup.com/Microsoft-Reactor-Redmond/events/282700053

Who is it aimed at?
If you are a part of the tech community or if you are interested in meeting people in the world of tech, this is an event you won’t want to miss.

Why should I attend?
If you miss connecting with your peers, join us to learn about fantastic community groups and meet industry professionals.

More about the groups we'll be joining!
PyLadies:
Seattle PyLadies is a Python programming group that welcomes members from all over the Puget Sound region. We started the Seattle chapter in 2012 and have grown to > 2000 members. PyLadies is an international mentorship group with a focus on helping more women become active participants and leaders in the Python open-source community. Our mission is to promote, educate and advance a diverse Python community through outreach, education, conferences, events and social gatherings.

Data Circles:
Data Circles started as Sea-WiDS (Seattle Women in Data Science). Data Circles exists to provide a place for women in data science to connect, build community, support each other and grow. Although we focus on empowerment of women, everybody is welcome to our events. We offer technical talks, workshops, networking opportunities, interview preparation sessions and more. Learn more about us at datacircles.org and, by joining the community you will enter our Slack space and connect to everyone in the community.

title: SoCal R Users Group (SoCal RUG): Short course: Nonparametric Analysis ***Eventbrite***, United States, US/Canada
description:
*** Sign-up on Eventbrite ****
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/socal-rug-nonparametric-analysis-a-primer-tickets-234310367617

This workshop will give you the practical skills and foundation knowledge to effectively use some of the most common nonparametric models used by data scientists. The classical statistical analysis is performed under the assumption that the underlying distribution of a variable of interest is known, or the sample size is sufficiently large (at least 30) so that the Central Limit Theorem starts working. This type of analysis is termed Parametric Statistics because all that needs to be done is to find estimates of distribution parameters and draw the inference based on these estimates. If, however, nothing is known about the underlying distribution and the sample size is small (less than 30), there will be no parameters to be estimated and a completely different methodology has to be applied to do statistical inference. The collection of methods, in this case, is called Nonparametric Statistics.

In this presentation, we will go over several most widely used nonparametric techniques. For each technique, just enough theory will be explained, followed by a thorough example or two, and then the audience will work on an exercise to reinforce understanding of the material.

The course will give examples in R and you will be taught how it create these models and interpret the output. You will work in small groups to do hands-on exercises to help reinforce the material.

Biography of Dr. Olga Korosteleva

Dr. Olga Korosteleva, is a professor of Statistics at the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at California State University, Long Beach (CSULB). She received her Bachelor’s degree in Mathematics in 1996 from Wayne State University in Detroit, and a Ph.D. in Statistics from Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana, in 2002. Since then she has been teaching mostly Statistics courses in the Master’s program in Applied Statistics at CSULB, and loving it!

Dr. Olga is an undergraduate advisor for students majoring in Mathematics with an option in Statistics. She is also the faculty supervisor for the Statistics Student Association. She is also the immediate past president of the Southern California Chapter of the American Statistical Association (SCASA). Dr. Olga is the editor-in-chief of SCASA’s monthly eNewsletter and the author (co-author) of four statistical books.

*** Sign-up on Eventbrite ****
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/socal-rug-nonparametric-analysis-a-primer-tickets-234310367617

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] DataSecOps – What It Is & How It Keeps Your Data Secure & Compliant  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Learn more and register here: https://info.datascience.salon/datasecops-what-it-is-and-how-it-keeps-your-data-secure-and-compliant

DataSecOps is an evolution in the way organizations treat security as part of their data operations. It is an understanding that security should be a continuous part of the data operations processes and not an afterthought.

As companies grow and data users expand, the need to secure sensitive personal information, including key areas such as health and financial data, becomes increasingly critical. To ensure this data is as safe as possible, security needs to be embedded into core data operations. Without this component, companies use ad-hoc processes and tools, leaving sensitive user data open to breaches from insiders, whether intentional or not.

The session will cover the best practices in securing sensitive personal, health and financial data with DataSecOps from hyper-growth startups including Wealthsimple, Canada’s largest fintech, ActiveCampaign, B2B SaaS Unicorn and Innovaccer, the healthcare technology disruptor.

Join Satori and discover how they created the first DataSecOps platform, which streamlines data access by automating access controls, security and compliance for the modern data infrastructure; and learn:

- The key elements and benefits of DataSecOps
- Why you should implement DataSecOps in your organization
- Key industries that can benefit from a DataSecOps program
- How a robust DataSecOps platform can ensure your data is secure and compliant
- DataSecOps predictions for 2022 and beyond

Learn more and register here: https://info.datascience.salon/datasecops-what-it-is-and-how-it-keeps-your-data-secure-and-compliant

title: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga: Taller aprendizaje de R: Analizando Spotify    [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
group: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga
description:
Hola a todos, primera charla de 2022. Retomamos la actividad del grupo y para ello el día 27/01 a las 19:00 daremos un taller de formación de R desde casi cero.

Este taller recoge una petición que nos ha llegado al grupo y nos parece bien retomar la actividad con este taller. Le daremos un enfoque nuevo en el sentido de usar la "filosofía" tidyverse para analizar el dataset.

Será online. Apuntarse al evento. Aquí en Meetup aparecerá el enlace de la videollamada (Google Meet).

El taller es de nivel inicial. Si necesitamos que tengáis instalado R y Rstudio en vuestro ordenador y descargado el dataset que vamos a analizar.

Importante:

- Instalar R y Rstudio en vuestro ordenador

- https://cran.rediris.es

- https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

- Descargarse el dataset de https://www.kaggle.com/leonardopena/top-spotify-songs-from-20102019-by-year

Analizaremos este dataset con información de Spotify. Podréis usar lo aprendido para analizar vuestros datos.

El objetivo es aprender lo básico de R (¡usando tidyverse!) para poder contestar algunas cuestiones:

- Mostrar todas las canciones de Taylor Swift en el último año. ¿Cuantas son?

- Los autores usan normalmente pocas palabras para dar nombre a las canciones. ¿Cierto?

- ¿Cuáles son las 10 canciones más escuchadas?

- ¿Cuantas canciones hay más populares de la media de popularidad de todas las canciones?

- ¿Cual son las canciones con más y menos energia (y sus autores)?

- ¿Cuáles son las 3 canciones más *bailables* de estilo pop a partir de 2016?

Os propondremos deberes: cuestiones de distinto nivel a responder por vosotros y ¿podríamos plantear una segunda sesión para responderlas y contestar dudas?

Os esperamos

Organizadores del Grupo

Jesús Dominguez, Domingo López, Antonio Matas, Ángel Mora, Joaquín Morís, Manolo Ojeda, Francisco Pérez , Ana Villalón

title: Oslo useR! Group: Cluster-Robust Standard Errors in R with {clubSandwich}   [Virtual] , Norway, Europe
description:
[About]
Cluster-robust variance estimation methods (also known as sandwich estimators, linearization estimators, or simply "clustered" standard errors) are a standard inferential tool in many different areas of applied statistics. They are appealing because they provide a means to do inference for regression models without relying on strong assumptions about the distribution or dependence structure of errors. However, standard cluster-robust variance estimators are based on large-sample approximations and can perform poorly when based on a small number of clusters.

In this talk, James will provide an overview of some refinements to cluster-robust variance estimators, as implemented in his package {clubSandwich} (https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=clubSandwich), that perform well even with a limited number of clusters.

He will provide a brief, high-level sketch of the theory behind the refined methods, discuss the practical rationale for using the methods, and demonstrate their application with the clubSandwich package, focusing in particular on linear mixed models. In addition to linear mixed models, the methods are available for a range of regression models and estimation methods, including ordinary least squares, weighted least squares, two-stage least squares, generalized linear models, and meta-regression models.

[Bio]
James Pustejovsky is a statistician and Associate Professor in the School of Education at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. His research involves developing statistical methods for problems in social science research, with a focus on methods for meta-analysis. He completed his Ph.D. in statistics from Northwestern University in 2013. His homepage is https://www.jepusto.com/

[Info]
The event will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/c/UseROslo

title: Wiesbaden R User Group: R Coffee Break: Key-Value Stores  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Hallo liebe R User,

Die R Coffee Break gibt einen kurzen Einblick (5 bis 10 Minuten) in ein R- Thema. Als Plattform nutzen wir Zoom.
Und ganz wie die gepflegte Kaffeepause im Büro wird das Meetup am Nachmittag stattfinden und insgesamt nicht länger als 15 Minuten in Anspruch nehmen.
In dieser R Coffee Break stellt Hans Werner Borchers uns das Thema "Key-Value-Stores" vor.
Die Datenstruktur der assoziativen Arrays ('Key-Value-Stores') ist für das Implementieren von Algorithmen von einiger Bedeutung, und ist unter ganz verschiedenen Bezeichnungen bekannt, z. B. 'dictionary' (Python, Julia), 'hash' (Perl, Ruby, JavaScript), 'map' (Java, Haskell) oder 'table' (Lua), usw. Wir werden uns einige R Pakete ansehen, die diese Funktionalität bereitstellen.

Wir freuen uns schon darauf euch bei diesem Meetup begrüßen zu dürfen. Die Zugangsdaten werden wie immer am Tag des Vortrags ab 12 Uhr hier bereitgestellt.

Kenncode: tbd

title: R Users Group, Gainesville, FL: R Learning Community (novice)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
These gatherings (about every 4 weeks) serve to to connect and introduce people to each other that use the R programming language for data wrangling, stats analysis, modeling, simulation, visualization, etc. We hope that these gatherings will foster a sense of community where we help each other out with coding and design, exchange ideas and forge collaborations.

The Learning Community gatherings are for novice and experienced R users. The main focus is on advancing novice's skills, and we'd like more experienced programmers to be there to share their knowledge!
We envision this as a flexible gathering: there will be no fixed start or end times, you can drop by any time between 3 and 5 pm (virtual or in-person). No official presentations. The format will be social, sit anywhere, talk to anyone, show your tips and amazing work to anyone. You can also just come and work on your R code, and ask questions whenever they arise.

The in-person location is the UFII classroom (CSE building, the glass walled offices facing Turlington Plaza). There will be coffee and snacks for those coming in-person :)
This event is open to everyone, not just those affiliated with UF!

title: R-Ladies Bariloche: GRUPO 3. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"  [Virtual] , Argentina, Latin America
description:
¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a comenzar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versión traducida al español de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes más!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ ¡Está muy bueno!

• Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 días para avanzar con la lectura y comprensión del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro será guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

• En el primer encuentro discutiremos el capitulo número 3 “visualización de datos” (¡Qué bueno, empezamos con gráficos con ggplot2 ) https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/visualizaci%C3%B3n-de-datos.html Es necesario llegar a la reunión con el capítulo previamente leído y trabajado. Quienes no leyeron la introducción del libro aún: adelante, es corta, y les dará un panorama de lo que iremos estudiando. En la reunión de organización vimos un panorama de la introducción.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: DuckDB, an In-Process Analytical DBMS  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Continuing the series of talks about using R with external computing, we have Hannes Mühleisen discussing DuckDB.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

About the Talk:
Using databases to wrangle and retrieve data from R and Python can be challenging, traditional systems like SQLite or MySQL are not built for analytical workloads and moving data into the analysis environment suffered from low bandwidth. DuckDB is a new in-process database management system that runs directly in-process, greatly streamlining setup and data transfer. DuckDB uses a column-vectorized query processing architecture to run analytical SQL queries very quickly indeed. DuckDB can also directly query data that lives in R or Pandas data frames and from external files without a dedicated data importing step. DuckDB is available as Free and Open Source software. In my talk, I will describe the rationale behind building DuckDB as well as give some usage examples for statistical programming.

About Hannes:
Hannes Mühleisen is a Senior Researcher in the Database Architectures Group at CWI Amsterdam, the Dutch National Research Center for Computer Science and Mathematics. Hannes is one of the creators of DuckDB, the first in-process analytical database management system. He is also co-founder and CEO of DuckDB Labs, a CWI spin-off to provide commercial services around the DuckDB project.

The talk will begin at 7 PM America/New_York and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: Vienna<-R: Oslo useR / ViennaR - Cluster-Robust Standard Errors in R with {clubSandwich}  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
Link to original event (organizer Meetup page)
>> https://www.meetup.com/Oslo-useR-Group/events/283050203/

Details:
[About]
Cluster-robust variance estimation methods (also known as sandwich estimators, linearization estimators, or simply "clustered" standard errors) are a standard inferential tool in many different areas of applied statistics. They are appealing because they provide a means to do inference for regression models without relying on strong assumptions about the distribution or dependence structure of errors. However, standard cluster-robust variance estimators are based on large-sample approximations and can perform poorly when based on a small number of clusters.

In this talk, James will provide an overview of some refinements to cluster-robust variance estimators, as implemented in his package {clubSandwich} (https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=clubSandwich), that perform well even with a limited number of clusters.

He will provide a brief, high-level sketch of the theory behind the refined methods, discuss the practical rationale for using the methods, and demonstrate their application with the clubSandwich package, focusing in particular on linear mixed models. In addition to linear mixed models, the methods are available for a range of regression models and estimation methods, including ordinary least squares, weighted least squares, two-stage least squares, generalized linear models, and meta-regression models.

[Bio]
James Pustejovsky is a statistician and Associate Professor in the School of Education at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. His research involves developing statistical methods for problems in social science research, with a focus on methods for meta-analysis. He completed his Ph.D. in statistics from Northwestern University in 2013. His homepage is https://www.jepusto.com/

[Info]
The event will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/c/UseROslo

title: R-Ladies Philly: 2022 Datathon Kickoff  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Do you want to practice your data skills while helping a good cause? Join R-Ladies Philly and DataPhilly for a 6-week datathon focused on exploring data for ElderNet, a local non-profit organization whose mission is to help elderly and disabled citizens maintain their independence at home. We will help them explore, stratify, and visualize their support services to ultimately tell a data story of ElderNet's impact in the Lower Merion and Narbeth region. We will be working on a deidentified subset of these data in order to:

- better understand the needs of our elderly and disabled population through data
- hone our data science skills
- learn and practice R, Python, and/or other languages you decide to use (there will be ways to contribute for people of all levels of experience with coding)
- get our hands dirty and our heads spinning with rich and messy real-world data
- work together, network, and make (new) friends in the data world!
- have fun nerding out together over data :)

The repository for the datathon can be found here: TBD

ElderNet: https://eldernetonline.org/about/

See you there!

title: R-Ladies Melbourne: Automate your CV using R Markdown: Easy as 1, 2, knit  [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
Hi Everyone!

We are very excited to announce R Ladies Melbourne's first event of 2022! This event will be presented by Dr. Shazia Ruybal-Pesántez, R Ladies Melbourne President and Postdoctoral Research Scientist at WEHI and Burnet Institute.

Updating your CV can be a tedious, but very necessary task! Most often this process involves creating and updating a user-created template in e.g. a Word document and fiddling with formatting for longer than one would like to admit, especially when it is time to update the content. With R Markdown, you can quickly turn your CV into a beautiful, automated document that is easy to produce, maintain and update to suit your specific needs. With this automated approach, the only thing you really have to worry about and devote your time to is writing the content.

In this talk, Shazia will take you through the R packages “datadrivencv”, “pagedown” and “vitae” that can be used with R Markdown to create and automate your CV. The aim is to guide you through how to save your data in a readable format for these packages, how to set up your R Markdown document, and how to render the output in different formats, all so that you can automate your pipeline to quickly and easily update your CV! This talk should give you sufficient information and materials that you can customize and either follow along during the talk or create your CV on your own after the talk.

This will be an online event. Please connect to the **lunchtime** zoom session at midday/12pm Melbourne time on Friday the 4th of February.

We look forward to seeing everyone at the event!

R-Ladies Melbourne

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Best of 2021: Data Wrangling with the tidyverse   [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
2021 was a great year for R-Ladies Freiburg! As the new year begins, let's review our favorite tips and tricks from last year's workshops.

In this first of two workshops, we'll go through the most life-changing data wrangling tips we learned last year. These commands make it easy to get your data in exactly the right format for graphs or statistical modeling and make your workflows more reproducible and less error-prone!

We'll end the hour-long workshop with a little data wrangling challenge for you to refresh your data wrangling skills. If you have less experience with data manipulation, don't hesitate to join, and if you're looking for a refresher, check out our past workshops on Youtube (https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLPwprT5wdzX7NVDl4oYQ7c2_6ox0_1fyr).

Image by Allison Horst (https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations).

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Best of 2021: Data Visualization with ggplot2  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
2021 was a great year for R-Ladies Freiburg! As the new year begins, let's review our favorite tips and tricks from last year's workshops.

In this workshops, we'll go through the tips and tricks that leveled up our plotting skills last year, from adding colors to fonts to annotations and more. We'll go over which additional packages and commands can help you make your plots just the way you imagined them!

We'll end the hour-long workshop with a visualization exercise where you can practice your plotting skills hands-on on your own. If you're just starting out with ggplot, feel free to join us, and check out our past workshops on Youtube for a little refresher (https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLPwprT5wdzX7NVDl4oYQ7c2_6ox0_1fyr).

Image by Allison Horst (https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations).

They are appealing because they provide a means to do inference for regression models without relying on strong assumptions about the distribution or dependence structure of errors. However, standard cluster-robust variance estimators are based on large-sample approximations and can perform poorly when based on a small number of clusters.

In this talk, James will provide an overview of some refinements to cluster-robust variance estimators, as implemented in his package {clubSandwich} (https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=clubSandwich), that perform well even with a limited number of clusters.

He will provide a brief, high-level sketch of the theory behind the refined methods, discuss the practical rationale for using the methods, and demonstrate their application with the clubSandwich package, focusing in particular on linear mixed models. In addition to linear mixed models, the methods are available for a range of regression models and estimation methods, including ordinary least squares, weighted least squares, two-stage least squares, generalized linear models, and meta-regression models.

[Bio]
James Pustejovsky is a statistician and Associate Professor in the School of Education at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. His research involves developing statistical methods for problems in social science research, with a focus on methods for meta-analysis. He completed his Ph.D. in statistics from Northwestern University in 2013. His homepage is https://www.jepusto.com/

title: R-Ladies East Lansing: Accessible DataViz  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Data visualizations and presentations are often unintentionally designed in a way that makes them inaccessible to a few participants. Come learn how to make your data visualizations and presentations accessible to everyone!

Fill out this Google Form to register, and you'll receive the Zoom link by email: https://forms.gle/RnR2jfqbWqGH7qWXA

Our first speaker, *Keke Wu* (PhD student at Univ of Colorado, Boulder) will talk about her research, Understanding Data Accessibility for People with Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities (IDD), giving us concrete ideas about how to make better figures and reach the IDD community.

Keke is a filmmaker, a storyteller, a designer, a developer, and a researcher. She has degrees in Digital Media Technology and Japanese Language and Literature, a Master of Fine Arts in Film and Television Production, and is currently working on her PhD in Creative Technology & Design at the University of Colorado Boulder. Her research focuses on visualization and accessibility through the lens of multimedia design and storytelling.

Website: https://www.kekewu.me/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/kekewu728

Our second speaker, *Andrea Gomez Vargas* (one of the winners of the 'most accessible presentation' award at useR! 2021), will talk about how to make an accessible presentation in R, using packages such as RMarkdown.

Andrea studied sociology at the University of Buenos Aires and is currently a sociologist, teacher, and researcher with a focus on gender studies and human rights. She is also a co-organizer of R Ladies Buenos Aires and a part of LatinR.

Website: https://soyandrea.netlify.app/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/me_andre

title: BernR: An Introduction to R with the Stanford Heart Transplant data (Part 2)  [Virtual] , Switzerland, Europe
description:
A presentation by Simon Schwab from Swisstransplant, Bern.

This is Part 2 of the talk. I will pick up the topics from last time and add more details. Also, it will be more interactive and I will directly take questions and requests from the audience.

The event takes place online. The link to the meeting will be visible for registered participants shortly before the beginning of the event (at the latest).

This is the first session of a new introductory series into R for beginners called "R Fundamentals". This first session gives a brief overview of R and RStudio:
- reading data (new: long and wide data tables)
- data types (new: subsetting data frames)
- exploring data (new: I x J crosstables, margins)
- some basic statistics (new: Pearson Chi-Square Test)
- figures with ggplot2 (if time allows)
- R Notebooks (if time allows)

Examples will be from Stanford Heart Transplant dataset from the "survival" package. Slides and materials (R notebook) will be made available before the session at https://osf.io/ex6v7/. Thus, if desired, the audience can interact with the data already during the session.

Future R Fundamentals will cover specific topics in more detail, e.g. data reading & data cleaning, ggplot2, descriptive statistics, etc.

講者簡介：

Ning Chen
Microsoft MVP
參與推動data for social good資料英雄計畫http://d4sg.org/fellowship/ ，此計劃運作六年，推動公益性質組織及公部門的大量營運數據發揮價值。歷年來，已經有超過40個政府機關及NGO透過這個計畫更加深入了解資料價值，輔導過社會及環保相關議題的資料分析案，2017~2022連續五年在AI類別取得微軟MVP榮譽，活耀於AI、機器學習相關研究、社群、競賽活動並且多場海內外AI相關專題演講經驗。帶領AI團隊與台北市社會救助科拿到聯發科「智在家鄉」百萬首獎。

陳奎銘（Benjamin Chen）
Momagic 的資料科學家和 Azure 講師
致力於用資料科學解決各個領域的疑難雜症，舉凡股票、期貨、廣告、生技醫療和環保，都有實務處理的經驗。除了資料科學以外，近年也投入參與 IoT 的開發與專利申請，開始進入跨足 AI、IoT、雲端的三棲狀態。

Kristen Chan
R-Ladies Taipei 現任負責人
喜歡學任何新鮮有趣的東西，期望能貢獻自己的能力運用資料解決問題。

Migo Liao
產品及使用者經驗優先原則的軟體工程師
作為協助者的特性，點了許多超出畫面及不務正業的技能樹。工作外喜歡學習不同領域的新知及參與NGO專案，盡最大努力去結合不同面向的跨領域經驗並落地到實務上。希望自己能成為 - 設身處地洞察生活難題，了解如何利用資訊科技來提供最佳解決途徑的愛貓人士，並完成更多對社會有正向影響力的事情。

孫玉峰
台灣角川數據架構師
在多個產業開發各種資料產品，包含推薦系統以及廣告數據平台（DMP／CDP），近年來的公開演講以及實務上則專注在資料工程與 MLOps 的建立，期望讓數據驅動（Data-Driven）的觀念帶動各個產業領域的創新。《數位時代》專欄作家、微軟最有價值專家（MVP）以及 Taiwan R User Group（常態活動 MLDM Monday 主辦單位）的共同主持人（Co-organizer）。

謝宗震 博士（Johnson）
Chimes AI（詠鋐智能）創辦人暨執行長、資料玩家、連續創業者、二寶爸 (夜奶餵食中)。
Has over 10 years of experience in machine learning. Able to play a key role to develop data products, make decisions and predictions from data. A devout believer in data science for anything good, when data scientist meet a domain expert.

title: R User Group Rhein-Neckar: March 2022: Startup Meeting of the Year  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
This is a placeholder for an online meeting we will have on March 15, 2022. This event will be followed by events on April 12, May 10, and June 14. Because of the omicron variant, all these meetings will still be online.

If there are no other, more statistically oriented proposals coming in during the next few weeks, there will be a talk on

* Solving Differential Equations with R
Differential equations play an important role in biology, chemistry, physics, engineering, economy, and other disciplines. In R they can be solved numerically with a few lines of code, and several packages support solving them. We will demonstrate this with some easy, but interesting examples.
(Talk in German or English, depending on the audience.)

After the talk, participants are invited to include a few mentions of R packages that have newly appeared on CRAN or have recently caught *their* special attention. One example (for me) is the 'mlpack' (see https://www.mlpack.org/) software that wraps a "fast, flexible C++ machine learning library". Is there any experience with using it?

See you online on Tuesday, March 15, 2022.

Suggestions of topics would be welcome. 'Lightning Talks' of 7-10 minutes and only very few (or no) slides are a good possibility, e.g. pointing out a package you would like to recommend or learn more about.

To avoid time restrictions, this video conference will be hosted on JITSI. To attend click the "online event" link on the right side, visible to all attendees, enter your name, and join the meeting.

Please only RSVP if you actually plan to attend.

title: R-Ladies RTP: [HYBRID] #tidytuesday Work Group (on a Thursday), United States, US/Canada
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event hybrid (zoom and face-to-face), where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

[TBD description of the dataset]

Agenda (all times in ET):
5:00 - 5:15 pm Meet & Greet
5:15 - 6:15 pm #tidytuesday
6:15 - 6:30 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post (https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt) and the main repository page (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday).

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
This event is a hybrid event. For those joining virtually, we will send you a email with a Zoom link the day before the event to everyone who RSVP'ed.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Teach Me How to Google  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Workshop description:

Googling for code help is something that all data scientists (at all career stages) do. But figuring out how to get the information you need back can be incredibly challenging, particularly for new coders. In this talk, we’ll discuss strategies for refining your queries to increase your chances of finding informative solutions.
https://samanthacsik.github.io/teach-me-how-to-google/slides/RLadiesSTL-2022-02-22.html#1

About the speaker:

Sam Csik (pronounced “chick”) is the Data Training Coordinator at the National Center for Ecological Analysis & Synthesis (NCEAS) located at UC Santa Barbara, where she is working to develop and teach data science training curricula for the Master’s of Environmental Data Science (MEDS) program and other data science initiatives across NCEAS and UCSB. She is also co-organizer of R-Ladies Santa Barbara, a local data science group which works to promote diversity in the R community. In her spare time, you’ll typically find her hiking with her pup or cooking family dinners with friends.

Link will be provided closer to the event.

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Creating Dynamic Reports from your Shiny App  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Workshop description:

So, you've created your wonderful, interactive Shiny app. But now you'd like to provide your users with a custom report that they can download. In this workshop, we'll start with a basic ready-made Shiny app (no need to build/bring your own!) and go over several packages that you can use to create dynamic reports with reactive Shiny elements.

About the speaker:

Sonja Winter (she/her) is a postdoctoral fellow at the Missouri Prevention Science Institute (MPSI) at the University of Missouri. She has worked on multiple Shiny apps that are used as educational and research tools. Prior to joining the MPSI, Sonja completed her Ph.D. in Quantitative Psychology at the University of California, Merced. Her research focuses on using Bayesian methods to resolve data analysis challenges in psychology and education.

Link will be provided closer to the event.

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Getting Started with Spatial Data  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Workshop Description:

In the first half of the spatial data workshop, we will discuss several datasets offered by the US Census Bureau, focusing primarily on the American Community Survey data, which remains underutilized across research disciplines. The workshop will (1) provide an overview of geographic hierarchies reported on by the Census (e.g., counties, tracts, blocks, zip code tabulation areas) and (2) demonstrate how to access valuable Census data using the Census API in R.

The second half of the workshop will focus on easy ways to create beautiful but straightforward maps using R packages such as sf, ggplot2, and leaflet.

About Josemari Feliciano:

Jose is a data scientist with the USDA Innovation Center in Washington, D.C. As a critical member of the USDA-Census Bureau equity research team, he performs research under the Census Bureau's Social, Economic, and Housing Statistics Division, where he studies the impact of federal investments in Rural America across racial and ethnic groups. Before USDA, he earned his MPH in Biostatistics from the Yale School of Public Health and worked as a software engineer at Google and Facebook.

title: RBelgium: The {tabnet} package, or how to outperform XGBoost and LightGBM on tabular data  [Virtual] , Belgium, Europe
description:
On Thursday, 3 February 2022 we are welcoming Christophe Regouby to RBelgium!

Christophe will present us: The {tabnet} package, or how to outperform XGBoost and LightGBM on tabular data, relying on {torch}

Google's TabNet (Arik & Pfister, 2019) is a state of the art modeling architecture for tabular data that enables interpretability and performance.
At the same time, {torch} raised Christophe's attention as being the center of a new friendly package ecosystem: the mlverse.

If you want to learn about TabNet, torch and self-supervised learning, join us online!

---

Christophe Regouby is a Data-scientist at Airbus' core AI team. He typically works on Document AI, NLP and data-visualization.

title: R-Ladies Gainesville: Creating and sharing R tutorials  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Online R tutorials are some of the most effective ways to troubleshoot problems and learn new skills. While we may appreciate tutorials, it can be hard to prioritize making our own to share with the R community. In this meeting, we'll kick off the R-Ladies Gainesville Tutorial Series!

Do you have a solution to a tricky R problem? Is there an R package you've been wanting to learn? The Tutorial Series will provide a framework for formalizing your knowledge, sharing it with other R-Ladies, and getting feedback. We will provide an introduction to tutorials and discuss approaches to making your own.

To follow along, we recommend having R and RStudio installed on your computer, as well as the "rmarkdown" and "tidyverse" R packages.

R-Ladies Gainesville welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling.

Please RSVP to access the Zoom link before the event.

Please note:
In line with R-Ladies’ Mission Statement to encourage participation in the R community by underrepresented genders/identities (https://rladies.org/about-us/), our events are designed for those individuals (including, but not limited to cis/trans women, trans men, non-binary, genderqueer, agender). title: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga: Taller aprendizaje de R: Analizando Spotify    [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
group: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga
description:
Hola a todos, primera charla de 2022. Retomamos la actividad del grupo y para ello el día 27/01 a las 19:00 daremos un taller de formación de R desde casi cero.

Este taller recoge una petición que nos ha llegado al grupo y nos parece bien retomar la actividad con este taller. Le daremos un enfoque nuevo en el sentido de usar la "filosofía" tidyverse para analizar el dataset.

Será online. Apuntarse al evento. Aquí en Meetup aparecerá el enlace de la videollamada (Google Meet).

El taller es de nivel inicial. Si necesitamos que tengáis instalado R y Rstudio en vuestro ordenador y descargado el dataset que vamos a analizar.

Importante:

- Instalar R y Rstudio en vuestro ordenador

- https://cran.rediris.es

- https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

- Descargarse el dataset de https://www.kaggle.com/leonardopena/top-spotify-songs-from-20102019-by-year

Analizaremos este dataset con información de Spotify. Podréis usar lo aprendido para analizar vuestros datos.

El objetivo es aprender lo básico de R (¡usando tidyverse!) para poder contestar algunas cuestiones:

- Mostrar todas las canciones de Taylor Swift en el último año. ¿Cuantas son?

- Los autores usan normalmente pocas palabras para dar nombre a las canciones. ¿Cierto?

- ¿Cuáles son las 10 canciones más escuchadas?

- ¿Cuantas canciones hay más populares de la media de popularidad de todas las canciones?

- ¿Cual son las canciones con más y menos energia (y sus autores)?

- ¿Cuáles son las 3 canciones más *bailables* de estilo pop a partir de 2016?

Os propondremos deberes: cuestiones de distinto nivel a responder por vosotros y ¿podríamos plantear una segunda sesión para responderlas y contestar dudas?

Os esperamos

Organizadores del Grupo

Jesús Dominguez, Domingo López, Antonio Matas, Ángel Mora, Joaquín Morís, Manolo Ojeda, Francisco Pérez , Ana Villalón
